member.summary: Rotation uses this point as a center point. Tells where to place the anchored point within the control area. For X dimension, value 0 represents left coordinate of the object and 1 right coordinate. For Y dimension, value 0 represents top coordinate of the object and 1 bottom coordinate. To define anchor point outside the object area, define values outside range 0...1.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Axes.AxisY.Fit(System.Double,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fit axis min and max to show all series values
member.param: Margin to leave between axis minimum or maximum and series values, in percents of min...max range
Method sets this true if Y axis minimum or maximum has changed
If true, all series points are searched, resulting to better accuracy, but with a cost raised CPU load.
Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting
member.remarks: For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behaviour.

members.member:
Fit axis min and max to show all series values, while keeping the range withing given limits
Margin to leave between axis minimum or maximum and series values, in percents of min...max range Method sets this true if Y axis minimum or maximum has changed If true, all series points are searched, resulting to better accuracy, but with a cost raised CPU load. Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behaviour. /// Minimum limit. If detected minimum is below limit minimum, the limit applies Maximum limit. If detected minimum is below limit minimum, the limit applies

member.summary: Fit axis min and max to show all series values
member.param: Margin to leave between data and segment boundaries, in pixels of min...max range
Method sets this true if Y axis minimum or maximum has changed

member.remarks: Works well for log axes too.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SeriesEventMarkerVerticalPosition.TrackSeries
member.summary: Track the series. The Y value is solved from X value. You can use this only for series implementing ITrackable interface Not applicable in X axis scrolling modes Scrolling, Stepping, Sweeping (monitoring modes). The resolver data is not valid for performance reasons. You should insert a marker as AtYValue in monitoring mode and convert it as TrackSeries when entering data review mode. Works only on series implementing ITrackable.

member.summary: Position at given Y value (series value, not coordinate)

member.summary: Bars are shown next to each other for same index value and fitted to view.

member.summary: Bars are shown in near-far view, first series in list nearest and last farthest. Bar X values control the position in X dimension. Series title is shown at the start or end edge of series.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.ErrorType.InvalidSeriesResolverDataWithSeriesEventMarker
member.summary: Series data X coordinate to Y coordinate resolver data has become invalid, because points have been added. Do not use markers as 'TrackSeries' with X axis monitoring monitoring scroll modes. Instead, you should define them as 'AtYValue' and convert them 'TrackSeries' when opening data in review mode, and set the scroll mode to 'None'.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.IGraphics
member.summary:
An interface that contains exactly the same methods as the GDI+ Graphics object. If your drawing routines draw to an IGraphics interface, then you can supply either a GdiGraphics object to render to the screen, or an object to render to an SVG file.
It's a pity that Graphics is a sealed class. Otherwise there'd be no need to have this interface or the class; we could simply derive a class from Graphics to do SVG output.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgElement
member.summary:
The base class for SVG elements. It represents some part of an SVG document, either an element (rect, circle etc) or a text item. Duties include:
Maintains a list of child elements and a list of attributes.
Writes itself and its children to an Xml document.
Reads itself and its children from an Xml document.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgFactory.LoadFromXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an xml document and (optionally) a particular element to start from, read the xml nodes and construct a tree of objects. Xml tags that do not correspond to a particular class will be represented by an . This means that literally any XML input can be read in and written out, even if it has nothing to do with Svg. More usefully, it means that new and unsupported tags and attributes will be represented in the SvgElement tree and written out correctly even if SvgNet does not understand them.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CompressXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary:
Helper function to compress long xml attributes into entities.
This would work on any XML, it is not SVG specific, so it should eventually be in some 'xml tools' class.
member.returns: A string of entities which can be inserted into the DOCTYPE when the document is written.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGdiNotImpl
member.summary: Exception thrown when a GDI+ operation is attempted on an IGraphics implementor that does not support the operation. For instance, SvgGraphics does not support any of the MeasureString methods.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics
member.summary:
This is an IGraphics implementor that builds up an SVG scene. Use it like a regular Graphics object, and call WriteXMLString to output SVG. In this way, whatever you would normally draw becomes available as an SVG document.
SvgGraphics has to do quite a lot of work to convert GDI instructions to SVG equivalents. Some things are approximated and slight differences will be noticed. Also, in several places GDI+ does not do what it is supposed to (e.g. arcs of non-circular ellipses, truncating bitmaps). In these cases SvgGraphics does do the right thing, so the result will be different.
Some GDI instructions such as MeasureString are meaningless in SVG, usually because there is no physical display device to refer to. When such a method is called an exception is thrown.
Many parameters used by GDI have no SVG equivalent -- for instance, GDI allows some fine control over how font hints are used. This detailed information is thrown away.
Some aspects of GDI that can be implemented in SVG are not. The most important omission is that only solid brushes are supported.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.WriteSVGString
member.summary: Get a string containing an SVG document. The very heart of SvgGdi. It calls WriteSVGString on the at the root of this SvgGraphics and returns the resulting string.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawString(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented.
In general, DrawString functions work, but it is impossible to guarantee that an SVG renderer will have a certain font and draw it in the same way as GDI+.
SVG does not do word wrapping and SvgGdi does not emulate it yet (although clipping is working). The plan is to wait till SVG 1.2 becomes available, since 1.2 contains text wrapping/flowing attributes.

member.summary: This method is implemented and produces a result which is often correct, but it is impossible to guarantee because 'MeasureString' is a fundamentally inapplicable to device independent output like SVG.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawIcon(System.Drawing.Icon,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Implemented. The DrawIcon group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented. The DrawImage group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.
The GDI+ documentation suggests that the 'Unscaled' functions should truncate the image. GDI+ does not actually do this, but SvgGraphics does.

member.summary: Implemented. There seems to be a GDI bug in that the image is *not* clipped to the rectangle. We do clip it.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.HandleBrush(System.Drawing.Brush)
member.summary:
When a GDI instruction with a brush parameter is called, there can be a lot we have to do to emulate the brush. The aim is to return a style that represents the brush.
Solid brush is very easy.
Linear grad brush: we ignore the blend curve and the transformation (and therefore the rotation parameter if any) Hatch brush:
Other types of brushes are too hard to emulate and are rendered pink.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.ChangeWhenAllPointsOnLine(System.Drawing.PointF[])
member.summary: MS Visio do ugly things if a line with clip should be drawn and all points on line are on the same x or y position. When the giben points are on a real horizontal or vertical line this function changes the first point for 0.0001.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.MatrixStack
member.summary:
This class is needed because GDI+ does not maintain a proper scene graph; rather it maintains a single transformation matrix which is applied to each new object. The matrix is saved and reloaded when 'begincontainer' and 'endcontainer' are called. SvgGraphics has to emulate this behaviour.
This matrix stack caches it's 'result' (ie. the current transformation, the product of all matrices). The result is recalculated when necessary.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTextElement
member.summary: Represents a text element. The SVG text element is unusual in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements (other elements like this are title, desc, and tspan). SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTspanElement
member.summary: Represents a tspan element. The tspan element is unique in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements. SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTitleElement
member.summary: Represents an SVG desc element. As with the SvgTextElement, the payload is in the enclosed text rather than in attributes and subelements, so we need to specially add text when serializing.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgDescElement
member.summary: Represents an SVG desc element. As with the SvgTextElement, the payload is in the enclosed text rather than in attributes and subelements, so we need to specially add text when serializing.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.LightningChartUltimate.MouseInteraction
member.summary: Allow mouse interaction. Mouse hit testing with objects cause CPU overhead when the mouse is moved. If mouse interaction is not absolute necessary directly within chart and if you want to maximize the performance, set this false.
member.remarks: Major part of mouse hit test overhead is caused by series testing. Series have MouseInteraction property too, so set at least that disabled while making real-time monitoring.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Maps.WeatherBugOptions.AutoUpdateThreshold
member.summary: Autoupdate cache tile refresh threshold. Use 0 to update always, regardless of cache tile date. Use 0.5 to update from cache, if cache tile timestamp is half of RefreshInvervalSeconds old or older. Use 1 to update from cache, if cache tile timestamp is RefreshInvervalSeconds old or older.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.MathRoutines.LinearFitSolveFactors(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculate linear fit from given points. Makes best fit with Least Square regression method. A line equation is y = k*x + b, that is, y = gradient * x + coefficient
member.param: Coefficient, Y value of intersection where X = 0
member.remarks: X values array lenght must be equal to Y values array length

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.MathRoutines.LinearRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Calculate linear line fit for given points
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
Polynomial result factors, length = order+1. For example, when having order 2, you can plot line with equation: Y = factors[0] + factors[1]*X + factors[2]*X^2
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Series3D.SurfaceSeries3DBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.LightningChartUltimate.BitmapAntialiasOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width x Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
Sets NegativeInfinity when bitmap pixel has alpha = 0.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries
member.summary: Freeform point line series. You can define the line and points style. Add points with AddPoints method.
member.remarks:
The points don't have to be in successive order by X value. If they are used in successive order in your application, you should use PointLineSeries or SampleDataSeries instead for optimal performance. Freeform point line series causes significantly higher CPU/GPU load than other line series types, when the series point count is high.
Note that the first array is not necessarily the first point of the series, as the Points array is a circular buffer.

member.summary: Limit point count by dropping oldest points. The point count is limited to PointCountLimit.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.PointCountLimit
member.summary: Point count limit. If you add points more than limited count, first points are automatically removed. The limiter only applies if PointCountLimitEnabled is true.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.OldestPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of oldest point in Points array. When PointCountLimitEnabled is true, the Points array is used as an circular point buffer. This is 0 always when PointCountLimitEnabled is false. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is 0: Read from index 0 till PointCount-1. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is > 0: First read from OldestPointIndex till PointCountLimit-1. Then read from index 0 till OldestPointIndex-1.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.LightningChartUltimate.BitmapAntialiasOptions)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width x Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.Created
member.summary: Is the device created. If false, the other fields of this structure are not valid.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.PureDevice
member.summary: True if optimal pure device mode is supported.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.FastVertexFormat
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports fast vertex format. Fast vertices are not available for old graphics adapters. If false, the rendering performance is not optimal, since slower vertex formats must be used. Getting a new graphics adapter is strongly recommended, ensure it is at least DirectX 10 level, for best performance.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.HardwareVertexProcessing
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports vertex processing in hardware (GPU). If false, the vertex calculation has to be done in software (computer CPU), and the performance is not optimal.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.ShaderModel3
member.summary: True if shader model 3 is supported. Both vertex and pixel shaders are format 3 or greater.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.IndexBuffers32Bit
member.summary: True if 32-bit index buffers are supported. If only 16-index buffers are supported, returns false. In this case the 3D surfaces may be limited into smaller sizes.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderDeviceInfo.TexturesSizesNonPowerOf2
member.summary: Limited support for textures which size is not power of two.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.MouseHitInfo3D.Button
member.summary: The mouse button which was pressed.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderingSettings
member.summary: Rendering settings, that can be given as chart constructor parameter. Speeds up creating of the chart, if non-default values are given, preventing the chart rendering engine to be re-created several times.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderingSettings.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderingSettings.WaitforVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn. Enabling this may improve performance especially in slow computers.

member.name: F:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.RenderingSettings.EffectCaching
member.summary: Effect caching. HLSL shaders are compiled into streams, enabling very fast chart resizing. It's recommeded to keep this enabled. But in Windows XP, disabling this property may give significant decrement in delay when rendering the chart first time. Disabling this will cause flickering when resizing the chart.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.CalculateAvgNormalsForIndexedTriangleList(Arction.LightningChartUltimate.DirectX.PositionNormalColored[],System.UInt32[],System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Speed optimized normals calculator for indexed triangle list. Prevents using any other method calls, if not absolutely necessary. This method is very performance critical when surfaces are large. Calculates averaged normals, for every common vertex.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.CalculateAvgNormalsForIndexedTriangleList(Arction.LightningChartUltimate.DirectX.PositionNormalTextured[],System.UInt32[],System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Speed optimized normals calculator for indexed triangle list. Prevents using any other method calls, if not absolutely necessary. This method is very performance critical when surfaces are large. Calculates averaged normals, for every common vertex.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.CalculateNormalsForNonIndexedTriangleList(Arction.LightningChartUltimate.DirectX.PositionNormalColored[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Speed optimized normals calculator for non-indexed triangle list. Prevents using any other method calls, if not absolutely necessary. This method is very performance critical when surfaces are large. Does not use averaged normals, because there's no info of adjacent vertices.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.CalculateNormalsPositionNormalTextured(Arction.LightningChartUltimate.DirectX.PositionNormalTextured[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Speed optimized normals calculator for non-indexed triangle list. Prevents using any other method calls, if not absolutely necessary. This method is very performance critical when surfaces are large. Does not use averaged normals, because there's no info of adjacent vertices.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.FixScaledMeshNormals(SharpDX.Direct3D9.Mesh,SharpDX.Matrix)
member.summary: Fix scaled mesh normals. When applying a scale matrix transform for a mesh, the normals get faulty. They must be inverse-transposed and the length must be normalized.
member.param: Matrix that is used in the scale transfrom

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.RayIntersectsTriangle(SharpDX.Ray@,SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a ray and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triagnle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: M:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Tools3D.CalculateLineLineIntersection(SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3,SharpDX.Vector3@,SharpDX.Vector3@)
member.summary: Calculates the intersection line segment between 2 lines. Returns false if no solution can be found.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.WaitForVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UseThreadPool
member.summary: Uses a thread pool for multicore processing. For some applications having a thread pool with hundreds of threads, you may want to disable this, to improve chart performance.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.MultiCoreProcessing
member.summary: Multicore processing. Divides computation in certain parts of the chart to several CPU cores to improve performance.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.MultiCoreCountLimit
member.summary: Multicore processing core count limit. For example, if you have 8 core processor, by setting this property System.Environment.ProcessorCount - 2 = 6, it will leave 2 cores free for other purposes.
member.remarks: Only effective when MultiCoreProcessing is set to LimitedToSelectedCount. If you set this higher than the actual core count is, actual core count is used.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.InvokeRenderingInUIThread
member.summary: Use thread safe updates to force the control draw itself though Invoke. Enabling this may cause slower updates, and should not be used in applications running without auxliary threads updating the chart data or properties. Alternatively, you can use Invoke method of your parent form or control. You should always update the chart data from by Invoking in application side.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.EffectCaching
member.summary: Effect caching. HLSL shaders are compiled into streams, enabling very fast chart resizing. It's recommeded to keep this enabled. But in Windows XP, disabling this property may give significant decrement in delay when rendering the chart first time. Disabling this will cause flickering when resizing the chart.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResize
member.summary: Update chart always when resizing control.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResizeTimeInterval
member.summary: Update chart after this interval (ms) after resizing ends, if UpdateAlwaysOnResize is false.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.RemoteDesktopVendorId
member.remarks: If remote desktop does not seem to work, set this value to GPU id.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.ForceDeviceCreateOnResize
member.summary: Force device create on control resize. Some virtual machine environment require this to be set to true.

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.View3D.BarViewOptions3D.StackSum
member.summary: Stack sum. The series values amongst different series are stacked and stretched to make this sum.
member.remarks: Effective only when Grouping is set to StackedStretchedToSum

member.name: P:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.View3D.BarViewOptions3D.BarSpacing
member.summary: Space between bars in same group as world values.

member.summary: Space between bar groups as world values, when grouping is fitted.

member.summary: Space between edge and nearest groups as world values, when grouping is fitted.

member.name: T:Arction.LightningChartUltimate.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer
member.summary: Persistent series rendering layer. Series can be rendered in a bitmap layer and the actual series freed. Saves a lot of memory, CPU and GPU resources, especially when rendering hundreds or thousands of series. The layer itself is rendered in the chart just before line series objects.
member.example: Consider a typical use case of FFT monitoring, where one data line series is collected periodically and added in the layer in full. The layer shows historic information of thousands of FFT strips. By using the persistent series layer, each series has millions of points, and the dozens of new strips can be added every second. By freeing the series itself after rendering it to the layer, the total memory consumption does not rise, and the system won't run out of memory even if the monitoring lasts several weeks.

member.summary: Allows decaying or bringing the layer more visible.
member.example: MultiplyAlpha(0.8) sets the alpha to 80% of existing alpha (decay). MultiplyAlpha(2) would adjust it to 200% (more visible).
